question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence.
She's under the a̲l̲l̲u̲s̲i̲o̲n̲ that she'll get the job.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: illusion

Explanation:
The correct word is "illusion", which means a false idea or belief — fitting perfectly in the sentence about mistaken hope or expectation.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • vision – Incorrect; means a vivid mental image or foresight, not necessarily false.

  • illusion – ✅ Correct; means a mistaken or misleading idea.

  • hallucination – Incorrect; means a false sensory perception, usually in a medical or psychological context.

  • unreality – Incorrect; means the state of being unreal, less commonly used and awkward here.

So, the improved sentence is:
"She's under the illusion that she'll get the job."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
She argued against the unnecessary s̲p̲l̲i̲t̲ in the committee.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: division

Explanation:
The word "split" here means a separation or disagreement within the committee.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • division – ✅ Correct; means the act of separating or splitting into parts, a perfect synonym.

  • mix – Incorrect; means to combine, opposite of split.

  • blend – Incorrect; means to mix smoothly, opposite of split.

  • combination – Incorrect; means joining or putting together, opposite of split.

So, the correct substitute for "split" is division.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the following sentence.
This serum contains ingredients e̲n̲a̲b̲l̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲h̲a̲i̲r̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲g̲r̲o̲w̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 4))
option_2: that enable the hair to grow
solution:
Correct Answer: that enable the hair to grow

Explanation:
The sentence describes ingredients that cause or allow the hair to grow. The correct relative clause is:

  • "that enable the hair to grow" — grammatically correct and clear.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • for growing many hair – Incorrect; awkward phrasing and "hair" is uncountable here.

  • that enable the hair to grow – ✅ Correct; proper use of relative pronoun and verb.

  • the enable grow hair – Incorrect; grammatically incorrect.

  • for growth hair – Incorrect; incomplete and ungrammatical phrase.

So, the improved sentence is:
"This serum contains ingredients that enable the hair to grow."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The meeting c̲l̲o̲s̲e̲d̲ with a vote of thanks.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 2))
solution:
Correct Answer: concluded

Explanation:
The phrase "closed with a vote of thanks" means the meeting ended formally with a speech of thanks. The best synonym that fits a formal context is "concluded."

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • stopped – Incorrect; informal and abrupt, not suitable for meetings.

  • finished – Incorrect; general term but less formal.

  • concluded – ✅ Correct; formal and appropriate for meetings.

  • completed – Incorrect; usually used for tasks, not for meetings.

So, the correct sentence is:
"The meeting concluded with a vote of thanks."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
He has recovered now and is feeling t̲o̲o̲ ̲s̲t̲r̲o̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲w̲a̲l̲k̲.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: strong enough to walk

Explanation:
The phrase "too strong to walk" is incorrect because "too" implies excessiveness, which doesn't fit here. The correct phrase is "strong enough to walk," meaning sufficiently strong to walk.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • too weak to walk – Incorrect; opposite meaning.

  • weak enough to walk – Incorrect; weak doesn’t fit the context.

  • strong enough to walk – ✅ Correct; means sufficiently strong to walk.

  • strong to walk – Incorrect; missing "enough."

So, the correct sentence is:
"He has recovered now and is feeling strong enough to walk."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
The e̲x̲p̲e̲r̲i̲e̲n̲c̲e̲d̲ surgeon handled the delicate procedure with care and precision.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: seasoned

Explanation:
The word "experienced" means having knowledge or skill gained over time.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • seasoned – ✅ Correct; means experienced and skilled.

  • untrained – Incorrect; means not trained.

  • unskilled – Incorrect; means lacking skill.

  • amateur – Incorrect; means inexperienced or non-professional.

So, the correct substitution for experienced is seasoned.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
The White man had to swallow his bombast and h̲a̲v̲e̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲p̲l̲e̲t̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲j̲o̲u̲r̲n̲e̲y̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲t̲i̲f̲i̲e̲d̲.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.10_08-Oct_Shift-2)
option_2: complete the journey in mortification
solution:
Correct answer: complete the journey in mortification

Explanation:

  • The phrase "have completed the journey in mortified" is incorrect because "mortified" is an adjective and does not fit here.

  • The correct noun form "mortification" should be used after "in".

  • Also, "have completed" should be changed to "complete" to maintain parallel structure after "had to swallow his bombast and...".

Correct sentence:
"The White man had to swallow his bombast and complete the journey in mortification."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment without changing its meaning in the given sentence.
Family planning programs play a crucial role in promoting reproductive health and empowering individuals to make informed choices, c̲o̲n̲t̲r̲i̲b̲u̲t̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲s̲u̲s̲t̲a̲i̲n̲a̲b̲l̲e̲ ̲p̲o̲p̲u̲l̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲g̲r̲o̲w̲t̲h̲ and a healthier society.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.11_08-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: promoting a viable population increase
option_2: discouraging a sustainable population upswing
option_3: fostering an unbalanced population growth
solution:
Correct answer: promoting a viable population increase

Explanation:

  • The original phrase "contributing to sustainable population growth" means helping maintain a balanced and healthy population increase.

  • "Promoting a viable population increase" closely matches this meaning, indicating support for a healthy, sustainable growth.

  • Other options:

  • Discouraging a sustainable population upswing – opposite meaning

  • Fostering an unbalanced population growth – negative meaning

  • Supporting sustainable population explosion – "explosion" implies uncontrolled growth, not sustainable

Correct sentence:
"Family planning programs play a crucial role in promoting reproductive health and empowering individuals to make informed choices, promoting a viable population increase and a healthier society."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
Solving the riddle given by our teacher is f̲a̲r̲t̲h̲e̲r̲ beyond our capacity.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.22_16-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: far

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"Solving the riddle given by our teacher is farther beyond our capacity."

Here, the underlined word "farther" is incorrect, because:

  • Farther is used for physical distance (e.g., farther down the road).

  • The sentence refers to degree or extent, not physical distance.

The correct word for expressing degree, extent, or level is "far."

Other options:

  • Fair – means just or light in colour; unrelated here.

  • Farthest – superlative form used to compare more than two distances.

  • Fare – means payment for travel; not related.

So the corrected sentence is:
"Solving the riddle given by our teacher is far beyond our capacity."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
Reduced price of cooking gas brought h̲a̲p̲p̲y̲ to the face of every citizen.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.25_17-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: happiness

Explanation:
The sentence requires a noun to fit the phrase "brought ______ to the face...".

  • Happiness is a noun meaning the state of being happy.
    (Hindi: खुशी) – ✅ Correct choice

Other options:

  • Happily – adverb, not suitable here

  • Happier – comparative adjective, incorrect form

  • Happiest – superlative adjective, incorrect form

Correct sentence:
"Reduced price of cooking gas brought happiness to the face of every citizen."

question:
Select the most appropriate form of comparative degree that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Maheshwari is three years j̲u̲n̲i̲o̲r̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ ̲m̲e̲.̲

(SSC MTS 2024 S.28_18-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: junior than any other to me
option_3: junior than that of me
solution:
Answer: junior to me

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"Maheshwari is three years junior than me."

  • The correct comparative structure for "junior" is "junior to" without "than."

  • Saying "junior to me" is grammatically correct.

  • Using "than" with "junior" is incorrect.

Correct sentence:
"Maheshwari is three years junior to me."

Other options are incorrect because:

  • junior than any other to me – awkward and incorrect structure

  • junior than that of me – incorrect

  • more junior than me – incorrect; "junior" already implies comparison

So, the correct phrase is "junior to me."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
It is essential that you a̲c̲t̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲a̲c̲c̲o̲r̲d̲a̲n̲c̲e̲ with the rules and regulations of the organisation.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.3_30-Sep_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer:comply

Explanation:

The sentence is: "It is essential that you act in accordance with the rules and regulations of the organisation."

The phrase "act in accordance with" means to follow, conform to, or obey rules or standards.

Let’s examine the options:

  • Comply – ✅ means to act according to a rule, request, or order, which is the closest meaning to "act in accordance with"

  • Obey – means to follow commands or orders, but it’s usually used with a person or authority rather than "rules and regulations" in formal context

  • Fulfill – means to complete or achieve (e.g., fulfill a promise) → not suitable here

  • Observe – can mean to follow rules, but is less direct than "comply" in formal usage

Therefore, "comply" is the most appropriate and precise substitute for the underlined segment.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution’.
There have been n̲u̲m̲e̲r̲o̲u̲s̲ attempts made by the citizens to restore parity.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.30_21-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: No substitution

Explanation:
The phrase "numerous attempts" is already correct and commonly used to mean many attempts. There is no need to change it.

Other options:

  • Quite numerous – redundant, less natural

  • Most numerous – implies the highest number, which may not fit the context

  • More numerous – comparative, but no comparison is made here

Correct sentence:
"There have been numerous attempts made by the citizens to restore parity."

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.35_22-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: Having beliefs in yourself is the bigger key to success.
option_2: Having belief in yourself is the big key to success.
option_3: Having belief in yourself is the biggest key to success.
option_4: Having belief in yourself is the most bigger key to success.
solution:
Answer:Having belief in yourself is the biggest key to success.

Explanation:

  • "Belief" is an uncountable noun, so "belief" (not "beliefs") is correct here.

  • We use "the biggest" to show the superlative degree, meaning the most important among all.

  • The phrase "most bigger" is grammatically incorrect because we don’t use "most" with "bigger" (which is already a comparative).

Other options errors:

  • "Having beliefs in yourself..." – ✘ "beliefs" should be "belief"

  • "big key to success" – ✘ should be "biggest" for superlative

  • "most bigger" – ✘ incorrect degree usage

Correct Sentence:
Having belief in yourself is the biggest key to success.

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence from the given options.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.35_22-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: It is strange to see a guy shouting in the mall without any reason.
option_2: It is too stranger to see a guy shout in the mall without any reason.
option_3: It is too stranger to see a guy shouting in the mall without any reason.
option_4: It is too stranger to see a guy shouting in the mall beside any reason.
solution:
Answer:It is strange to see a guy shouting in the mall without any reason.

Explanation:
This sentence is grammatically correct and clearly expresses the idea.

Let’s break it down:

  • "strange" – correct adjective form (not "stranger", which is the comparative form)

  • "to see a guy shouting" – correct usage of the -ing form after "see" to describe an ongoing action

  • "without any reason" – means "with no clear cause" and is correctly used

Errors in other options:

  • "too stranger" – ✘ incorrect; "stranger" is comparative and cannot be used with "too"

  • "shout" – ✘ incorrect after "see" in this context (we expect the -ing form: "shouting")

  • "beside any reason" – ✘ incorrect phrase; "beside" means "next to", not "without"

✅ Correct sentence:
It is strange to see a guy shouting in the mall without any reason.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
B̲y̲ ̲d̲e̲f̲i̲n̲i̲t̲i̲o̲n̲,̲ ̲m̲a̲k̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲a̲ ̲p̲i̲c̲t̲o̲g̲r̲a̲m̲ is to present and visualise data.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.38_23-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: In making a pictogram, the definition
option_2: The purpose of a pictorgram
option_3: Pictogram is making a definition
option_4: To make a pictogram by definition
solution:
Answer:The purpose of a pictogram

Explanation:
The original sentence is awkward and grammatically incorrect:
"By definition, making a pictogram is to present and visualise data."

We need a clearer and more natural expression of the function or purpose of a pictogram.

  • "The purpose of a pictogram" fits perfectly, as it clearly introduces the role pictograms play → ✅

  • "In making a pictogram, the definition" – awkward and unclear → ❌

  • "Pictogram is making a definition" – grammatically incorrect and illogical → ❌

  • "To make a pictogram by definition" – confusing structure and unclear meaning → ❌

Correct sentence:
The purpose of a pictogram is to present and visualise data.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the sentence.
She was deeply effected by the news, to the point of tears.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.4_01-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer:affected by

Explanation:

The sentence is: "She was deeply effected by the news, to the point of tears."
The underlined word "effected" is incorrect in this context.

Let’s clarify:

  • Effected (verb) means brought about or caused to happen, e.g., "The manager effected major changes." → ❌ doesn't fit here

  • Affected (verb) means influenced emotionally or mentally → ✅ appropriate for describing someone emotionally moved by news

Now review the options:

  • Effected from – ❌ incorrect verb + preposition

  • Affected by – ✅ grammatically and contextually correct

  • Affect from – ❌ “affect” is a verb; “from” is the wrong preposition

  • Affected of – ❌ incorrect prepositional usage

Therefore, the correct substitution is: affected by.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The intersection of nature conservation and social justice is e̲v̲i̲d̲e̲n̲t̲ ̲i̲n̲ ̲e̲f̲f̲o̲r̲t̲s̲ ̲t̲o̲ ̲e̲n̲s̲u̲r̲e̲ that marginalised communities and other backward classes should have equal access to natural reserves.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: apparent in endeavours to guarantee
option_2: Unclear in initiatives to safeguard
option_3: Manifest in actions to redesign
option_4: obvious in attempts to recollect
solution:
Answer:apparent in endeavours to guarantee

Explanation:
The original phrase is:
"evident in efforts to ensure that marginalised communities..."
This means something is clearly visible or noticeable in the actions taken to provide equal access.

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • apparent in endeavours to guarantee –

  • Apparent means clearly visible – स्पष्ट

  • Endeavours means efforts – प्रयास

  • Guarantee means to ensure or secure something – सुनिश्चित करना
    → ✅ This perfectly substitutes the original phrase.

  • Unclear in initiatives to safeguard – ❌ "Unclear" is the opposite of "evident"

  • Manifest in actions to redesign – ❌ "Redesign" doesn’t fit the context of equal access

  • Obvious in attempts to recollect – ❌ "Recollect" means to remember, which is unrelated

So, the best substitution is "apparent in endeavours to guarantee".

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
It is worth noting that the possible from him being voted as the class monitor is next to zero.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.42_29-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:possibility of him

Explanation:
The sentence is:
It is worth noting that the possible from him being voted as the class monitor is next to zero.

The word "possible" is incorrectly used here as a noun. We need the noun form to match the phrase "is next to zero."

  • "Possibility" is the correct noun form of "possible" and is used to talk about chances or likelihood – संभावना

  • The correct preposition after "possibility" in this context is "of".

So, the correct phrase is "possibility of him being voted..."

Correct sentence:
It is worth noting that the possibility of him being voted as the class monitor is next to zero.

question:
Correct the underlined part of the sentence.
They have a f̲e̲w̲ juice in the jar.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.44_29-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:little

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"They have a few juice in the jar."

This is incorrect because "juice" is an uncountable noun, and with uncountable nouns we use "little", not "few".

Let’s examine the options:

  • lesser – ❌ Used for comparison, not suitable here

  • fewer – ❌ Used with countable nouns

  • least – ❌ Superlative; not correct in this context

  • little – ✅ Correct word to use with uncountable nouns like "juice"

Correct sentence:
They have a little juice in the jar.

little – used for a small amount of an uncountable item – थोड़ा (Hindi meaning)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment without changing its meaning in the given sentence.
Entrepreneurial e̲n̲d̲e̲a̲v̲o̲u̲r̲s̲ ̲d̲r̲i̲v̲e̲ ̲e̲c̲o̲n̲o̲m̲i̲c̲ ̲g̲r̲o̲w̲t̲h̲ and innovation, empowering individuals to bring their ideas to fruition.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.46_30-Oct_Shift-2)
option_3: ventures contribute to economic flourishing
solution:
Answer: c) ventures contribute to economic flourishing

Explanation:
The phrase "entrepreneurial endeavours drive economic growth" means that new business efforts help the economy grow and promote innovation.

  • "Entrepreneurial endeavours" = business efforts or risky business activities → best matched by "ventures" (new and risky business actions)

  • "Drive economic growth" = support or help the economy grow → best matched by "contribute to economic flourishing"
     • Contribute = to help or add to something (योगदान देना)
     • Flourishing = growing successfully or doing well (तेजी से बढ़ना, फलना-फूलना)

Why other options are wrong:

  • (a) actions spur economic recession → Recession = economic decline (आर्थिक गिरावट), which is the opposite of growth

  • (b) pursuits manipulates economic success → Manipulates = to control dishonestly (धोखे से या चालाकी से नियंत्रित करना), which is a negative word

  • (d) projects discourage economic prosperity → Discourage = to prevent or stop (रोकना), Prosperity = wealth and success (समृद्धि), again the opposite of growth and innovation

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the highlighted word(s) in the given sentence.
 Mr. Wilson is elder than he looks.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.50_04-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: a) older than

Explanation:
The sentence is: "Mr. Wilson is elder than he looks."
This is incorrect because:

  • "Elder" is used only for family relationships (e.g., my elder brother).

  • For general age comparison (like in this sentence), we use "older than".

Correct sentence:
"Mr. Wilson is older than he looks."

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Elder for and elder to = grammatically incorrect in this context

  • Older then = wrong use of "then" instead of "than"

Only "older than" is the correct and appropriate substitution.

question:
Select the word segment that substitutes the bracketed word segment correctly and completes the sentence meaningfully.
The movie was (mostly over) when we entered the hall.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.52_05-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: almost over

Explanation:
The phrase "almost over" correctly means nearly finished (लगभग समाप्त).

  • More done and most done are incorrect and unnatural.

  • Most over is grammatically wrong.

Only "almost over" fits the context and meaning properly.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Autumn leaves s̲h̲u̲f̲f̲l̲e̲d̲ ̲b̲e̲n̲e̲a̲t̲h̲ ̲h̲i̲m̲ as he wandered through the quiet forest.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.61_13-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: rustled underfoot

Explanation:
The phrase "shuffle beneath him" describes the sound and movement of leaves as someone walks over them.

  • Rustled underfoot means the soft, crackling sound leaves make when stepped on (पैरों के नीचे सरसराना), which fits perfectly.

  • Died over is incorrect and doesn’t make sense here.

  • Crushed around means being flattened but lacks the sound element.

  • Moved to another place doesn’t describe the sound or immediate movement underfoot.

So, "rustled underfoot" is the best substitute.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
The nation has chosen the government by the people over monarchy.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (20 Jan))
solution:
Explanation:

Democracy refers to a system of government where the citizens have the power to make decisions, often through voting.

In this context, "government by the people" aligns best with democracy.

The other options are:

Oligarchy is a form of government where power is concentrated in the hands of a small group.

Theocracy is a system of government where priests or religious figures govern in the name of a deity.

Autocracy is a system where one person has absolute power.

Thus, Option 4 is the right answer.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words in the given sentence.
In the makeshift place of activity, debate or conflict, there were hundreds of people with the queen's team of advisors and servants sitting within the ring against the wall.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-2 (20 Jan))
solution:
Explanation:

Arena refers to a place or scene of activity, debate, or conflict. In historical contexts, it often denotes a central area where events or contests are held, such as in ancient Roman amphitheaters. In modern usage, it can describe any venue where significant events or activities occur.

The other options are:

Aviary is a large enclosure for confining birds.

Dormitory is a building or room providing sleeping accommodations for a number of people.

Casino is a facility for certain types of gambling activities.

Thus, Option 1 is the correct answer.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the following sentence.
Selling, purchasing, and using a̲n̲ ̲i̲l̲l̲e̲g̲a̲l̲l̲y̲ ̲c̲o̲p̲i̲e̲d̲ product is a criminal offence.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 1_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 2
Solution: The correct substitution is a pirated. The phrase “illegally copied product” refers specifically to a pirated item, especially in the context of media, software, or branded goods (पाइरेटेड उत्पाद – जो अवैध रूप से कॉपी किया गया हो).
Option 1 – an outlawed: means banned by law (कानून द्वारा निषिद्ध), but doesn’t specifically refer to copying.
Option 3 – a crooked: means dishonest or corrupt (बेईमान), which is too general and not contextually accurate.
Option 4 – an obsolete: means outdated or no longer in use (पुराना, अप्रचलित); unrelated to copying or illegality.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
With all their little comforts destroyed, the survivors were thrown s̲t̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲f̲a̲r̲t̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲b̲a̲c̲k̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲o̲ ̲b̲a̲r̲b̲a̲r̲i̲s̲m̲.̲

(SSC MTS 2023 : 1_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: still further back into barbarism
option_2: still further back for barbarism
option_3: still a little farther into barbarism
solution:
Answer: 1
Solution: The correct improvement is "still further back into barbarism."

The phrase "further back into barbarism" is more appropriate when referring to a figurative or abstract movement, like a regression in culture or civilisation.

  • "Further" is used for figurative or abstract distance, while "farther" typically refers to physical distance.

  • The sentence talks about a descent into a primitive state, which is abstract — hence "further" is correct.

Option 2 – still further back for barbarism ❌: incorrect preposition; "for" doesn’t fit here.
Option 3 – still a little farther into barbarism ❌: changes the meaning; "a little farther" weakens the intensity and "farther" suggests physical distance.
Option 4 – No improvement required ❌: incorrect, because "farther" is not suitable for figurative context.

So, the best and grammatically accurate choice is “still further back into barbarism.”

question:
Select the option that substitutes the bracketed word-segment correctly and completes the sentence meaningfully.
Manthan and Pranav (sang together in a concert).

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-1)
option_1: articulated together in a show
option_2: enunciated together in a show
option_3: chanted together in a show
option_4: enjoined together in a show
solution:
Answer: 3 (chanted together in a show)

Solution:
The original sentence is:
"Manthan and Pranav (sang together in a concert)."
We need a suitable word that replaces “sang together” in a context that fits a concert or performance.

✔ "Chanted together in a show" is the most appropriate.
The word “chant” means to sing or say something repeatedly in a rhythmic tone, which is often done in musical or concert settings.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Articulated – means spoke clearly; not suitable for singing.

  • Enunciated – means pronounced words clearly; used in speaking, not in singing.

  • Enjoined – means instructed or urged someone to do something; doesn’t fit at all.

Correct sentence:
"Manthan and Pranav chanted together in a show."

Word Meanings:

  • Chanted – sung in rhythm or tone (गाया, स्वर में दोहराया)

  • Articulated – spoken clearly (साफ उच्चारण किया)

  • Enunciated – pronounced precisely (स्पष्ट रूप से बोला)

  • Enjoined – commanded or urged (आज्ञा दी)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined word in the given sentence.
None of the countries involved in war were ready to b̲r̲o̲a̲c̲h̲ the issue of retreat.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 3 – bring up for discussion

Solution (Correct Option – 3: bring up for discussion):
The word broach means to bring up a subject or issue for discussion, especially one that may be sensitive or difficult.
In the sentence, “None of the countries involved in war were ready to broach the issue of retreat,” it means they were unwilling to discuss the possibility of retreat.

Broach – to bring up for discussion (किसी कठिन या संवेदनशील विषय को चर्चा के लिए उठाना)

Why other options are incorrect:
Turn down thoughtlessly – Means to reject without thinking (बिना सोचे मना करना), unrelated to discussion.
Underestimate the worth of – Means to judge something as less valuable (महत्त्व को कम आंकना), not relevant here.
Disregard contemptuously – Means to ignore with disrespect (घृणा से अनदेखा करना), which is not the meaning of “broach”.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
What e̲x̲a̲c̲t̲l̲y̲ ̲i̲s̲ ̲y̲o̲u̲r̲ problem with me?

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 3 – No improvement required

Solution (Correct Option – 3: No improvement required):
The sentence "What exactly is your problem with me?" is grammatically and structurally correct.
The word “exactly” is an adverb used appropriately here to ask for a specific or precise explanation.

What exactly is your problem – तुम्हारी समस्या आखिर है क्या? (सटीक रूप से जानने के लिए पूछा गया प्रश्न)

Why other options are incorrect:
Definitely is your – “Definitely” means surely (निश्चित रूप से), which doesn’t fit in this context.
Finally is your – “Finally” refers to something happening at the end (आख़िरकार), irrelevant here.
Entirely is your – “Entirely” means completely (पूरी तरह), but doesn't fit idiomatically in this sentence.

So, no improvement is required.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to replace the underlined word in the given sentence.
 Rama has been very u̲n̲l̲u̲c̲k̲y̲ in the last few years.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 4 – hapless

Solution (Correct Option – 4: hapless):
The underlined word "unlucky" means having bad luck or experiencing unfortunate events.
The most appropriate synonym from the given options is “hapless”, which also means unfortunate or unlucky, especially in a helpless way.

Hapless – दुर्भाग्यशाली, बदकिस्मत

Why other options are incorrect:
Unnerving – Means disturbing or causing anxiety (घबराहट पैदा करने वाला)
Degraded – Means lowered in dignity or quality (गिरा हुआ या अपमानित), unrelated
Undeserving – Means not worthy (अयोग्य), which doesn’t mean “unlucky”

Therefore, hapless is the best fit for replacing “unlucky”.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Seeing the danger of a̲ ̲g̲r̲o̲u̲p̲ ̲g̲o̲v̲e̲r̲n̲e̲d̲ ̲b̲y̲ ̲o̲l̲d̲ ̲p̲e̲o̲p̲l̲e̲,̲ Ratan planned to recruit young people for his project.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 4 – gerontocracy

Solution (Correct Option – 4: gerontocracy):
The underlined phrase “a group governed by old people” perfectly defines the term “gerontocracy.”

  • Gerontocracy refers to a form of government or rule by a group of elderly people (वृद्धों द्वारा शासित शासन प्रणाली).

Gerontocracy – बुज़ुर्गों द्वारा चलाया जाने वाला शासन या संगठन

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Adhocracy – A system with flexible and informal structure, opposite of hierarchy

  • Autocracy – Rule by one individual with absolute power (तानाशाही)

  • Plutocracy – Government or control by the wealthy (धनाढ्यों का शासन)

So, gerontocracy is the correct one-word substitute for the given phrase.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to replace the underlined word in the given sentence.
There is no r̲e̲a̲s̲o̲n̲ for him to be angry.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 11 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 2

Solution (Correct Option – 2: logic):
The sentence is:
“There is no reason for him to be angry.”
Here, the word “reason” means a basis or justification for something, and the most appropriate synonym in this context is “logic”, which also means a valid or sensible explanation (तर्क).

Revised sentence:
“There is no logic for him to be angry.”

Why other options are incorrect:
Sanity – Refers to mental stability (मानसिक संतुलन), not a synonym for reason.
Lucidity – Means clarity (स्पष्टता), especially in expression or thought — not the same as justification.
Argument – A verbal exchange or a debate; doesn’t fit this context precisely.

Word Meaning:
Logic – Sound reasoning or valid explanation (तर्क, उचित कारण)
Reason – Justification or cause for something (कारण)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
The application of the medicine seemed to ̲l̲e̲s̲s̲o̲n̲ his pain.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 11 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 1

Solution (Correct Option – 1: lessen):
The correct word is “lessen”, which means to reduce or make something smaller in amount, degree, or severity (कम करना).
The sentence should read:
“The application of the medicine seemed to lessen his pain.”

Why other options are incorrect:
lesion – Means an area of damage or injury to tissue (घाव); irrelevant in this context.
No substitution required – Incorrect, because “lesson” is a noun and doesn't fit here as a verb.
lessoned – Not a valid verb form; “lesson” is not used as a verb meaning "reduce".

Difficult Word Meaning:
Lessen – To reduce or decrease (कम करना)
Pain – Physical or emotional suffering (दर्द)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
Jeremy does not like to discuss his p̲e̲r̲s̲o̲n̲n̲e̲l̲ ̲p̲r̲o̲b̲l̲e̲m̲s̲ openly.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 11 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 3

Solution (Correct Option – 3: personal problems):
The phrase “personnel problems” is incorrect in this context.

  • Personnel refers to employees or staff (कर्मचारी), not private matters.

  • The sentence is about Jeremy’s own private issues, so the correct term is “personal problems”, which means issues related to one’s private life (व्यक्तिगत समस्याएं).

Correct sentence:
“Jeremy does not like to discuss his personal problems openly.”

Why other options are incorrect:

  • No substitution required – Incorrect; the current phrase uses the wrong word.

  • Personnel problem – Refers to HR or staff-related issues, not Jeremy’s personal life.

  • Person problem – Grammatically and contextually incorrect.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Personal – Relating to a person’s private life (व्यक्तिगत)
Personnel – People employed in an organisation (कर्मचारी)

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined words.
A̲ ̲g̲o̲v̲e̲r̲n̲m̲e̲n̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲t̲a̲k̲e̲s̲ ̲d̲e̲c̲i̲s̲i̲o̲n̲s̲ ̲b̲a̲s̲e̲d̲ ̲o̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲r̲e̲c̲o̲m̲m̲e̲n̲d̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲s̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲s̲t̲a̲t̲e̲ ̲o̲f̲f̲i̲c̲i̲a̲l̲s̲ instead of elected representatives

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 11 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 4

Solution (Correct Option – 4: Bureaucracy):
The underlined phrase describes a system of government where decisions are made by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
This is the exact definition of “Bureaucracy”.

Example: In a bureaucracy, policies and decisions are often made by unelected officials following set procedures.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Gerontocracy – Rule by old people (वृद्धों का शासन)

  • Democracy – Rule by the people through elected representatives (लोकतंत्र)

  • Autocracy – Rule by one person with absolute power (तानाशाही)

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.
We m̲i̲g̲h̲t̲ ̲a̲s̲ ̲w̲e̲l̲l̲ watch a film on TV as there’s nothing much to do.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

✅ Why it's correct:

  • The phrase “might as well” is an idiomatic expression used to suggest doing something because there's no better alternative or nothing else to do.

  • Meaning: “Since there’s nothing better to do, let’s do this.”
    (जैसे तैसे कुछ कर ही लें)

✅ The sentence is already grammatically and idiomatically correct.

❌ Why other options are incorrect:

  • may as such – Not a valid English expression

  • might well – Has a different meaning (indicating likelihood, not suggestion)
    ➤ Example: He might well win the match.

  • may as well as – Grammatically incorrect and awkward

✔️ Final Answer: No improvement required ✅

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The excessive u̲s̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲p̲o̲c̲k̲e̲t̲ ̲c̲a̲l̲c̲u̲l̲a̲t̲o̲r̲s̲ can stultify your capacity to do mental calculations.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: use of pocket calculators

"Use of pocket calculators" - This is the correct option. It changes the structure to "use of," which accurately conveys the intended meaning of the original sentence. It adheres to standard grammatical usage.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The scientist says that while the complete core meltdown at Chernobyl was a major disaster, i̲t̲ ̲h̲a̲d̲ ̲f̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲f̲a̲r̲ ̲s̲h̲o̲r̲t̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲c̲a̲t̲a̲s̲t̲r̲o̲p̲h̲e̲ many nuclear power critics had feared, the so-called ‘China Syndrome’.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
option_1: it fell far short of the catastrophe
option_2: it fell much short of the catastrophe
option_3: it fell far away of the catastrophe
option_4: it fell far shorter of the catastrophe
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: it fell far short of the catastrophe

The original sentence uses "it had fallen," which is in past perfect tense. The corrected option changes it to "it fell," which is in the past simple tense. This provides a smoother and more concise expression of the idea. The phrase "far short of the catastrophe" is a clear and idiomatic way to convey that the actual outcome was much less severe than what critics had feared.

Corrected option: "The scientist says that while the complete core meltdown at Chernobyl was a major disaster, it fell far short of the catastrophe many nuclear power critics had feared, the so-called ‘China Syndrome.’"

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Nobody knew Ramesh was coming to see us. He arrived s̲u̲d̲d̲e̲n̲l̲y̲.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment "suddenly" in the given sentence is: "unexpectedly"

suddenly: occurring or done quickly and unexpectedly or without warning.

unexpectedly: in a way that was not foreseen or anticipated; without warning.

safely: in a manner that is free from harm, danger, or risk.

angrily: in a manner characterized by anger or strong displeasure.

happily: in a joyful, content, or pleased manner.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Extraordinary students are c̲o̲n̲t̲r̲o̲l̲l̲e̲d̲ ̲t̲h̲i̲n̲k̲e̲r̲s̲ ̲a̲n̲d̲ ̲c̲r̲e̲a̲t̲o̲r̲s̲ who learn best when their training is dynamic, approachable and project-based.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence is: "independent thinkers and creators"

The most appropriate substitution is "independent thinkers and creators" because it aligns with the positive qualities associated with extraordinary students. It implies that these students have the freedom and autonomy in their thinking and creative processes.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
River rafting is an adventure sport in which a group of five people l̲e̲v̲i̲t̲a̲t̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲r̲o̲u̲g̲h̲ ̲a̲ ̲r̲i̲v̲e̲r̲ in an inflatable raft.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
solution:
Answer: d) navigate through a river

Explanation:
The underlined verb "levitate" means to float in the air, usually without support — this is incorrect and illogical in the context of river rafting.

We need a verb that means to move or travel through the river, which is what rafters do.

  • Correct verb: navigate → means to guide or travel through a route or path (मार्ग से गुजरना / दिशा देना)

✔ So, the correct phrase is:
“…a group of five people navigate through a river…”

Why other options are incorrect:

  • deviate – means to change direction (भटकना) ❌ not suitable

  • assemble – means to gather (इकट्ठा होना) ❌ unrelated to movement

  • alleviate – means to reduce pain/suffering (कम करना) ❌ irrelevant in this context

Only “navigate” fits both grammatically and contextually.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The heart that is f̲u̲l̲l̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲g̲r̲i̲e̲v̲e̲ is heavy.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
solution:
Answer: b) full of grief

Explanation:
The underlined phrase “full of grieve” is incorrect because “grieve” is a verb, but we need a noun to describe what the heart is full of.

  • “Grief” is the correct noun form meaning deep sorrow or sadness (शोक, गहरा दुख).

  • So, the correct phrase is: “full of grief”.

Correct sentence:
“The heart that is full of grief is heavy.”

Why other options are incorrect:

  • a) filled with grieve – ❌ “grieve” is a verb; should be “grief”

  • c) filling with grief – ❌ wrong tense/form for the sentence structure

  • d) full of grieving – ❌ awkward and less natural; “grieving” is a gerund, not ideal here

Only option (b) is grammatically correct and natural in usage.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Some teachers often praise their pupils' efforts while some use ridicule and i̲r̲o̲n̲y̲.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
solution:
Answer: d) sarcasm

Explanation:
The underlined word “irony” is often confused with “sarcasm”, but in this context, the better substitute is “sarcasm”.

  • Irony is when the opposite of what is expected happens or is said, often subtly.

  • Sarcasm is a harsh or mocking remark, often intended to hurt or criticise (ताना मारना).

  • Since the sentence contrasts praise with ridicule, the better word for mocking or hurtful speech is sarcasm.

Correct sentence:
“Some teachers often praise their pupils' efforts while some use ridicule and sarcasm.”

Why other options are incorrect:

  • vigilant – means alert or watchful (सतर्क) → ❌ unrelated

  • appreciation – opposite in tone (सराहना) → ❌ doesn't match with “ridicule”

  • abuse – too harsh; doesn't fit the balanced contrast of the sentence ❌

Only “sarcasm” fits both grammatically and contextually.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the following sentence.
His research on the migratory patterns of the birds is r̲u̲n̲-̲o̲f̲-̲t̲h̲e̲-̲m̲i̲l̲l̲.̲

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
The most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the sentence is: Average

So, the corrected sentence would be: "His research on the migratory patterns of the birds is average." This implies that the research is ordinary or commonplace.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If no substitution is required, select ‘No substitution required’.
“Can you give me s̲o̲ ̲m̲a̲n̲y̲ ̲e̲x̲a̲m̲p̲l̲e̲s̲ ̲o̲f̲ subordinate clauses?”, the teacher asked the class.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 13 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Correct Answer: some more examples of

Solution:
The phrase “so many examples of” is incorrect in this context. The sentence is a polite request, and the correct phrase to use is “some more examples of”, which fits naturally when asking for additional items.

  • "So many" is usually used to emphasize a large number, not to make a polite or specific request.

  • "some more" correctly conveys a request for additional examples.

Other options are incorrect:

  • "some many" – grammatically incorrect combination

  • "some few" – awkward and rarely used, implies limitation

Meanings:
subordinate clause – a part of a sentence that depends on the main clause – आश्रित उपवाक्य
example – a sample or illustration – उदाहरण
some more – additional – कुछ और

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The knowledge and abilities that students are expected to master as they p̲r̲o̲g̲r̲e̲s̲s̲ ̲t̲h̲r̲o̲u̲g̲h̲ the four years of high school are referred to as the high school curriculum.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
solution:
Answer: a) advance through

Explanation:
The phrase “progress through” means to move forward or advance through a period or process (आगे बढ़ना).

  • The best substitute is “advance through”, which also means to move forward step by step over time.

Other options are incorrect because:

  • “regress along” – means to move backward, opposite of progress

  • “grow with” – not suitable here, as it means to develop alongside something

  • “deteriorate over” – means to get worse, opposite meaning

Hence, “advance through” is the most appropriate substitute for “progress through.”

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
The manager of the hotel requested the boarder to mention his w̲h̲e̲r̲e̲a̲b̲o̲u̲t̲s̲ in the register.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
option_2: motif of the heinous crime
solution:
Answer: a) place of residence

Explanation:
The word “whereabouts” refers to the location or place where someone lives or can be found (स्थान या पता).

  • The sentence talks about the manager asking the boarder to mention his whereabouts in the register, meaning his place of residence.

Other options are unrelated:

  • motif of the heinous crime – motive behind a serious crime (अपराध का कारण) ❌

  • aftermath of the offence – consequences of a crime (अपराध के बाद की स्थिति) ❌

  • reason of moral degradation – cause of decline in moral standards (नैतिक पतन का कारण) ❌

Only “place of residence” correctly substitutes “whereabouts” here.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
N̲e̲w̲t̲o̲n̲ ̲f̲o̲u̲n̲d̲ ̲o̲u̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲t̲ the force of gravitation makes the apples fall.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
Answer: Newton discovered that

Explanation:
The correct verb to use with finding out a natural fact or scientific truth is "discovered."

  • Discovered means to find out something new or unknown (खोज निकालना).

  • Newton is famous for discovering the law of gravitation.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Popularised – means made something well-known (प्रसिद्ध बनाना) ❌

  • Invented – means created something new, usually man-made (आविष्कार करना) ❌

  • Registered – means officially recorded (पंजीकृत करना) ❌

Hence, “discovered” is the best fit in this sentence.
